awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Response of Continental Hydrothermal Systems to Tectonic, Magmatic, and Climatic Forcing
awd_abstract_narration:
Continental hydrothermal systems have immense scientific and practical significance and are critically important to the Earth?s thermal budget and geochemical cycles. Continental hydrothermal systems are a primary source of economically important metal deposits, provide geothermal resources, support exotic ecosystems that are just beginning to be explored, and in some settings pose a significant geologic hazard via hydrothermal explosions. The subsurface conditions and processes that control these systems are poorly understood because they entail the flow of multi-phase and multi-component fluids through rocks with heterogeneous permeability fields that are perturbed by a multitude of geological and environmental processes. Carefully designed multidisciplinary field experiments and modeling efforts are 
required to understand the coupled processes that drive these dynamic systems and control their response to geological and environmental forcing. This project is focused on quantifying the response of continental hydrothermal systems to tectonic, magmatic, and climatic processes operating on time-scales from seconds to thousands of years. The PIs address important and timely scientific questions, such as: How do multi-phase fluids and dissolved constituents flux through hydrothermal systems? How do these systems redistribute elements to produce mineral deposits and microbial habitats? How do earthquakes and magmatic activity perturb hydrothermal systems? What triggers hydrothermal explosions? How do environmental processes and climate affect continental hydrothermal systems? 

The study will involve a combination of fieldwork, data analysis, and modeling. The field program uses a combination of innovative instrument networks and sediment coring activities that will be integrated through modeling activities to study the response of the Yellowstone Lake hydrothermal system to tectonic, magmatic, and climatic forcing. Yellowstone Lake is an ideal site for this research because it hosts an active hydrothermal system located in a region with high levels of tectonic and magmatic activity that has been influenced by a broad range of climate conditions in postglacial times. Research activities will include components of geochemistry, seismology, geology, geodesy, heat flow, micropaleontology, limnology, paleoclimatology, statistics, analytical modeling, and numerical modeling, all of which are essential for unraveling the coupled processes that drive system behavior. Working on a lake-floor system provides an exceptional opportunity to study forcing-response relationships on an expanded range of time-scales spanning more than 11 orders of magnitude.

por.por_cntn:
Yellowstone National Park is well-known for its many hydrothermal features, including Old Faithful, Mammoth Hot Springs, and the Upper Geyser Basin. Less obvious are the hydrothermal vents and deposits that are hidden from view on the floor of Yellowstone Lake. The number and location of these hydrothermal vents have shifted throughout the lake?s history, and the intensity of hydrothermal venting has waxed and waned through time.

 

We used multiple sediment cores that penetrated the floor of Yellowstone Lake and into the mud below to examine the history of hydrothermal activity in the lake and the impacts of hydrothermal explosions on terrestrial ecosystems and on the biology and chemistry of the lake. The cores span the time since the recession of the local >1-km-thick Pinedale ice sheet, at the end of the last ice age approximately 14,000 years ago. The cores were sampled for 1) pollen to reconstruct vegetation history; 2) charcoal as a measure of fire activity; 3) diatoms as a major algal group in the lake that responds to changes in the chemistry and physical dynamics of the lake (lake temperature and water level); 4) several geochemical variables that reflect nutrients required for diatom growth, lake water balance, and hydrothermal activity; 5) sedimentary structures; and 6) radiocarbon analyses to date the timing of geologic events. The geochemical measurements included some relatively new tools (δ30Si and Ge/Si of diatoms) that are more widely used in marine studies but that have not been applied in investigations of lakes and their history. 

 

The sedimentary record of the lake provides abundant evidence of active faulting around the lake, multiple hydrothermal explosions, hydrothermally driven sediment deformation, and large-scale slumping of sediments from shallow water into deep. Two major hydrothermal explosions, Mary Bay at 13,000 years ago and Elliott's Crater at 8,000 years ago, were massive events and are evident in many cores throughout the lake. The Mary Bay explosion formed one of the largest explosion craters in the world, nearly 2.6 km in diameter, and produced the northeastern-most basin of the modern lake. Triggering mechanisms for these massive hydrothermal explosions are related to local seismic activity and sudden lake-level changes. The sediment record suggests that these big explosions also may have produced a tsunami in the lake. The most recent hydrothermal explosion was a small young event about 150 years ago. 

 

Despite recurrent hydrothermal disturbances in and near Yellowstone Lake, the long-term development of vegetation and fire activity in the Yellowstone Lake watershed and the diatom community composition of the lake show little long-term change associated with these events. Similarly, no changes were seen in the geochemical records to suggest a significant influence of the hydrothermal explosions on lake level, lake water balance, or silica cycling. Instead, the terrestrial and lake records are better explained as a response to changing Holocene climate. 

 

This project involved a large interdisciplinary research team that spanned multiple fields within geosciences. Project data have been contributed to NSF-supported databases and will be available to other scientists and the public. The project trained two US PhD students, who are continuing geoscience research in other US universities. It also trained several undergraduate research assistants who learned varied techniques for biological and geochemical analysis of geologic samples. Together the team produced about a dozen peer-reviewed manuscripts, including several led by the early-career scientists. The research results enhance our understanding of both the frequency of these unusual geologic hazards and of the ecosystem response to short-term disturbances, as well as past climate change. Together, this study contributes information on how organisms and landscapes might respond and adapt in a rapidly changing future.
